content: This contribution hasnâ€™t received enough positive votes from the community. The "SHORTEST" option has therefore been deactivated.

This is a really tough clash. The only way to really solve it is to do a brute force solution, then find the pattern manually and then code up a hacky solution (O(1)) using the pattern to skip all the brute force work...

It's a bit frustrating to have to do so much debugging to find a solution that the statement isn't able to tell you. I just got it in fastest mode and no one solved it. I came 2nd with 16% and lost to a bot who got 33%
In Constraints, I changed 0<N to 0<=N, as the tests contain instances with N=0

For future reference, this puzzle is a prequel to the puzzle "Hit or miss"
https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/1884240d123fecedc64eb4fa840ed33e275a

This one is very interesting. But I'm really not sure. While the O(n) solution is easy to implement (maybe a little too much), the O(1) sound tricky to understand (in only 15 minutes). I'm sure a lot of people will give up with only the basic solution. Maybe giving a hint about the cyclical nature of the sequence will fix that.

I have two questions about this puzzle, please read this before approving or rejecting:

-I've named my test cases a bit memey, is this okay? Or should I change them to be more descriptive?
-Are my tests too long? I've tried to test them and 1 out of 8 times CG couldn't respond to my validation request. Is this problematic? Or is it something CG related?

Edit: I've tested further more and I never got the request timeout again, maybe it was something CG related for that moment
The tests seems OK to me, both for name and length.

That's also one of my concerns. Currently I'm thinking of giving a poetic-esque hint at the end with a sentence like:

A distant voice whispers, the clocks! They are predictable aren't they? Visiting the exact same minute every day. Maybe everything has a limit...

Or is it still obscure? Should I just go with a simple sentence like:

Hint: Think in cycles
You do a lot of efforts for the narration, but .. yeah, really obscure. The second one sound better (to me).

Aight, I've appended the line "Hint: Think in cycles, maybe there's a way to predict the future" at the end of the puzzle, hope it didn't spoil the solution a lot. Also, is there a way to use italic in CG?
The problem is probably a bit too hard, but whatever, it's great, so...
I didn't notice the test case names until you've said it. Better than the default "Test X" name TBH.
